info.title: Cognite API
info.description:
# Introduction
This is the reference documentation for the Cognite API with 
an overview of all the available methods.

# Pagination
Most resource types can be paginated, indicated by the field `nextCursor` in the response.
By passing the value of `nextCursor` as the cursor you will get the next page of `limit` results.
Note that all parameters except `cursor` has to stay the same.

# Parallel retrieval
If you want to download a lot of resources (let's say events), paginating through millions of records can be slow.
We support parallel retrieval through the `partition` parameter, which has the format `m/n` where `n` is the amount of partitions you would like to split the entire data set into.
If you want to download the entire data set by splitting it into 10 partitions, you would do the following in parallel with `m` running from 1 to 10:
  - Make a request to `/events` with `partition=m/10`.
  - Paginate through the response by following the cursor as explained above. Note that the `partition` parameter needs to be passed to all subqueries.

get.description: List all assets, or only the assets matching the specified query.

parameters.name: parentIds
parameters.description: List only assets that have one of the IDs as a parent.

parameters.name: rootIds
parameters.description: The IDs of the root assets that the assets should be children of.

schema.description: The source of the asset, for example which database it's from.
Whether the filtered assets are root assets, or not. Set to True to only list root assets.

x-code-samples.source: const assets = await client.assets.list({ filter: { name: '21PT1019' } });

post.description: You can create a maximum of 1000 assets per request.

requestBody.description: List of the assets to create. You can create a maximum of 1000 assets per request.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import Asset
assets = [Asset(name="asset1"), Asset(name="asset2")]
res = client.assets.create(assets)

get.summary: Retrieve an asset by its ID
get.description: Retrieve an asset by its ID. If you want to retrieve assets by externalIds, use Retrieve assets instead.

post.description: Use advanced filtering options to find assets.

x-code-samples.source: const assets = await client.assets.list({ filter: { name: '21PT1019' } });

post.description: Retrieve assets by IDs or external IDs.

requestBody.description: All provided IDs and external IDs must be unique.

post.description: Update the attributes of assets.

requestBody.description: All provided IDs and external IDs must be unique. Fields that are not included in the request, are not changed.

x-code-samples.source: const assets = await client.assets.update([{id: 123, update: {name: {set: 'New name'}}}]);

asset = client.assets.retrieve(id=1)
asset.description = "New description"
res = client.assets.update(asset)
from cognite.client.data_classes import AssetUpdate
my_update = AssetUpdate(id=1).description.set("New description").metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.assets.update(my_update)

post.description: Search for assets based on relevance. You can also use advanced filtering options as in Filter assets, and then search in the results from the filter. Returns the first 1000 results based on relevance.

requestBody.description: Search query

x-code-samples.source:
res = client.assets.search(name="some name")
res = client.assets.search(filter={"name": "some name"})
res = client.assets.search(name="xyz",filter={"parent_ids": [123,456],"source": "some source"})

post.description: Delete assets. To delete all descendants, set recursive to true. The limit of the request does not include the number of descendants that are deleted.
Creates multiple event objects in the same project. It is possible to post a maximum of 1000 events per request.

requestBody.description: List of events to be posted. It is possible to post a maximum of 1000 events per request.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import Event
events = [Event(start_time=0, end_time=1), Event(start_time=2, end_time=3)]
res = client.events.create(events)

get.description: List events optionally filtered on query parameters

parameters.name: assetIds
parameters.description: Asset IDs of related equipment that this event relates to. Format is list of IDs serialized as JSON array(int64). Takes [ 1 .. 100 ] of unique items.

parameters.name: rootAssetIds
parameters.description: The IDs of the root assets that the assets should be children of.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description:
Sort by array of selected fields. Syntax: `["<fieldname>:asc|desc"]`. Default sort order is `asc` with short syntax: `["<fieldname>"]`. 
Filter accepts the following field names: startTime, endTime, createdTime, lastUpdatedTime. 
Partitions are done independently of sorting, there is no guarantee on sort order between elements from different partitions.

x-code-samples.source: const events = await client.events.list({ filter: { startTime: { min: new Date('1 jan 2018') }, endTime: { max: new Date('1 jan 2019') } } });

post.description: Retrieve a list of all events in the same project. This operation supports pagination by cursor. Criteria can be applied to select a subset of events.

x-code-samples.source: const events = await client.events.list({ filter: { startTime: { min: new Date('1 jan 2018') }, endTime: { max: new Date('1 jan 2019') } } });

post.description:
Retrieves information about events in the same project. Events are returned in the same order as the ids listed in the query.

A maximum of 1000 event IDs may be listed per request and all of them must be unique.

requestBody.description: List of IDs of events to retrieve. Must be up to a maximum of 1000 IDs, and all of them must be unique.

post.description:
Updates events in the same project. This operation supports partial updates; Fields omitted from queries will remain unchanged on objects.

For primitive fields (String, Long, Int), use 'set': 'value' to update value; use 'setNull': true to set that field to null.

For the Json Array field (e.g. assetIds), use 'set': [value1, value2] to update value; use 'add': [v1, v2] to add values to current list of values; use 'remove': [v1, v2] to remove these values from current list of values if exists.

A maximum of 1000 events can be updated per request, and all of the event IDs must be unique.

requestBody.description: List of changes. A maximum of 1000 events can be updated per request, and all of the event IDs must be unique.

x-code-samples.source: const events = await client.events.update([{id: 123, update: {description: {set: 'New description'}}}]);

event = client.events.retrieve(id=1)
event.description = "New description"
res = client.events.update(event)
from cognite.client.data_classes import EventUpdate
my_update = EventUpdate(id=1).description.set("New description").metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.events.update(my_update)

post.description: Deletes events with the given ids. A maximum of 1000 events can be deleted per request.

requestBody.description: List of IDs to delete.

post.description:
Create metadata information and get upload link for one file.

The uploadUrl link which is returned in the response is a Google Cloud Storage (GCS) resumable upload URL. 
It should be used in a separate request to upload the file, as documented in 
https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/json_api/v1/how-tos/resumable-upload. 

The uploadUrl expires after one week. 
Any file info entry that do not have the actual file uploaded within one week will be automatically deleted.

The 'Origin' header parameter is forwarded as a 'Origin' header to the GCS initiate upload session request.
Also, the 'mimeType' query parameter is forwarded as a 'X-Upload-Content-Type' header.

parameters.name: Origin
parameters.description: The 'Origin' header parameter is required in a resumable upload request if there is a Cross Origin issue.

parameters.name: overwrite
parameters.description:
If 'overwrite' is set to true, and the POST body content specifies a 'externalId' field, fields for the file found for externalId can be overwritten. The default setting is false. 

If metadata is included in the request body, all of the original metadata will be overwritten.
The actual file will be overwritten after a successful upload with the uploadUrl from the response. 
If there is no successful upload, the current file contents will be kept. 

File-Asset mappings only change if explicitly stated in the assetIds field of the POST json body. 
Do not set assetIds in request body if you want to keep the current file-asset mappings.

requestBody.description: Fields to be set for the file.

x-code-samples.source:
res = client.files.upload("/path/to/file", name="my_file")
res = client.files.upload("/path/to/file")
res = client.files.upload("/path/to/my/directory")

get.description:
The GET /files operation can be used to return information for all files in a project. 

Optionally you can add one or more of the following query parameters. 
The filter query parameters will filter the results to only include files that match all filter parameters.

parameters.name: rootAssetIds
parameters.description: The internal IDs of the root assets that the related assets should be a descendant of (or match).

parameters.name: minSourceCreatedTime
parameters.description: Include files that have sourceCreatedTime set and with minimum this value.

parameters.name: maxSourceCreatedTime
parameters.description: Include files that have sourceCreatedTime set and with maximum this value.

parameters.name: minSourceModifiedTime
parameters.description: Include files that have sourceModifiedTime set and with minimum this value.

parameters.name: maxSourceModifiedTime
parameters.description: Include files that have sourceModifiedTime set and with maximum this value.

parameters.name: uploaded
parameters.description: Whether or not the actual file is uploaded. This field is returned only by the API, it has no effect in a post body.

get.description: Returns file info for the file ID

post.description: Retrieves a list of all files in a project. Criteria can be supplied to select a subset of files. This operation supports pagination with cursors.

requestBody.description: The project name

post.description:
Retrieves metadata information about multiple specific files in the same project. 
Results are returned in the same order as in the request. This operation does not return the file contents.

requestBody.description: List of IDs of files to retrieve. Must be up to a maximum of 1000 IDs, and all of them must be unique.

post.description: Search for files based on relevance. You can also supply a strict match filter as in Filter files, and search in the results from the filter. Returns first 1000 results based on relevance. This operation supports limited pagination with the offset parameter, but does not support retrieving all files in a project.

Deletes the files with the given ids.

A maximum of 1000 files can be deleted per request.

requestBody.description: List of IDs of files to delete.

post.description: Retrieves a list of download URLs for the specified list of file IDs. After getting the download links, the client has to issue a GET request to the returned URLs, which will respond with the contents of the file. The link will expire after 30 seconds.

requestBody.description: List of file IDs to retrieve the download URL for.
The JSON request body which specifies which files and fields to update.

x-code-samples.source:
file_metadata = client.files.retrieve(id=1)
file_metadata.description = "New description"
res = client.files.update(file_metadata)
from cognite.client.data_classes import FileMetadataUpdate
my_update = FileMetadataUpdate(id=1).source.set("new source").metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.files.update(my_update)

get.description:
Retrieve the contents of a 3D file.

This endpoint supported tag-based caching.

This endpoint is only compatible with 3D file IDs from the 3D API, and not compatible with
file IDs from the Files API.

parameters.name: threedFileId
parameters.description: The ID of the 3D file to retrieve.

schema.description: The raw contents of the file.

Content-Type.description: The media type of the file.

get.description: Retrieves a list of all models in a project. This operation supports pagination. You can filter out all models without a published revision.

parameters.name: published
parameters.description: Filter based on whether or not it has published revisions.

x-code-samples.source: const models3D = await client.models3D.list({ published: true });

requestBody.description: The models to create.

201.description: A list of the created models.

requestBody.description: List of changes.

200.description: Corresponding models after applying the updates.

x-code-samples.source:
three_d_model = client.three_d.models.retrieve(id=1)
three_d_model.name = "New Name"
res = client.three_d.models.update(three_d_model)
from cognite.client.data_classes import ThreeDModelUpdate
my_update = ThreeDModelUpdate(id=1).name.set("New Name")
res = client.three_d.models.update(my_update)

requestBody.description: List of models to delete.

get.description: Retrieves a list of all revisions of a model. This operation supports pagination. You can also filter revisions if they are marked as published or not by using the query param published.

parameters.name: published
parameters.description: Filter based on published status.

requestBody.description: The revisions to create.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import ThreeDModelRevision
my_revision = ThreeDModelRevision(file_id=1)
res = client.three_d.revisions.create(model_id=1, revision=my_revision)

requestBody.description: List of changes.

200.description: Corresponding revisions after applying the updates.

x-code-samples.source:
revision = client.three_d.revisions.retrieve(model_id=1, id=1)
revision.status = "New Status"
res = client.three_d.revisions.update(model_id=1, item=revision)
from cognite.client.data_classes import ThreeDModelRevisionUpdate
my_update = ThreeDModelRevisionUpdate(id=1).published.set(False).metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.three_d.revisions.update(model_id=1, item=my_update)

requestBody.description: List of revisions ids to delete.
The request body containing the file ID of the thumbnail image (from Files API).

get.description: Retrieves a list of nodes from the hierarchy in the 3D model. You can also request a specific subtree with the 'nodeId' query parameter and limit the depth of the resulting subtree with the 'depth' query parameter. This operation supports pagination.

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: Get sub nodes up to this many levels below the specified node. Depth 0 is the root node.

parameters.name: nodeId
parameters.description: ID of a node that are the root of the subtree you request (default is the root node).

parameters.name: properties
parameters.description:
Example: `{"category1":{"property1":"value1"}}`

Filter for node properties. Only nodes that match all the given properties exactly will be listed.
The filter must be a JSON object with the same format as the `properties` field.

post.description: Retrieves specific nodes given by a list of IDs.

requestBody.description: The request body containing the IDs of the nodes to retrieve.

get.description: Retrieves a list of ancestor nodes of a given node, including itself, in the hierarchy of the 3D model. This operation supports pagination.

parameters.name: nodeId
parameters.description: ID of the node to get the ancestors of.

get.description:
List all asset mappings


Asset references obtained from a mapping - through asset ids - may be
invalid, simply by the non-transactional nature of HTTP.
They are NOT maintained by any means from CDF, meaning they will be stored until the
reference is removed through the delete endpoint of 3d asset mappings.

parameters.name: intersectsBoundingBox
parameters.description:
Example: `{"min":[0.0, 0.0, 0.0], "max":[1.0, 1.0, 1.0]}`

If given, only return asset mappings for assets whose bounding box
intersects the given bounding box.

Must be a JSON object with `min`, `max` arrays of coordinates.

post.description:
Create asset mappings


Asset references when creating a mapping - through asset ids - are allowed to be
invalid.
They are NOT maintained by any means from CDF, meaning they will be stored until the
reference is removed through the delete endpoint of 3d asset mappings.

requestBody.description: The asset mappings to create.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import ThreeDAssetMapping
my_mapping = ThreeDAssetMapping(node_id=1, asset_id=1)
res = client.three_d.asset_mappings.create(model_id=1, revision_id=1, asset_mapping=my_mapping)

post.description: Delete a list of asset mappings

requestBody.description: The IDs of the asset mappings to delete.

post.description:
Lists 3D assets mappings that match the specified filter parameter. Only
one type of filter can be specified for each request, either `assetIds` or `nodeIds`.


Asset references obtained from a mapping - through asset ids - may be
invalid, simply by the non-transactional nature of HTTP.
They are NOT maintained by any means from CDF, meaning they will be stored until the
reference is removed through the delete endpoint of 3d asset mappings.

200.description: A list of matching asset mappings.

get.description: List time series. Use nextCursor to paginate through the results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limits the number of results to return. CDF returns a maximum of 1000 results even if you specify a higher limit.

parameters.name: includeMetadata
parameters.description: Whether the metadata field should be returned, or not.

parameters.name: assetIds
parameters.description: Get the time series related to the assets. The format is a list of IDs serialized as a JSON array(int64). Takes [ 1 .. 100 ] unique items.

parameters.name: rootAssetIds
parameters.description: The IDs of the root assets that the related assets should be a descendant of (or match).

200.description: A list of time series in lexicographic order.

x-code-samples.source: const timeseries = await client.timeseries.list({ includeMetadata: false, assetIds: [1, 2] });

post.description: Create one or more time series.

409.description: A time series with the specified externalId already exists.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import TimeSeries
ts = client.time_series.create(TimeSeries(name="my ts"))

post.description: Retrieve one or more time series by ID or external ID. The time series are returned in the same order as in the request.

requestBody.description: List of the IDs of the time series to retrieve.

200.description: List of time series matching the IDs.

post.description: Retrieves a list of time series matching the specified criteria. This operation supports pagination by cursor. Criteria can be applied to select a subset of time series.
Retrieves a list of time series matching the specified criteria. This operation does not support pagination.

parameters.name: project
parameters.description: Project name.

post.description:
Updates one or more time series. Fields that are not included in the request, are not changed.

For primitive fields (String, Long Int), use 'set': 'value' to update the value; use 'setNull': true to set the field to null.

For JSON Array fields (for example securityCategories), use 'set': [value1, value2] to update the value; use 'add': [v1, v2] to add values; use 'remove': [v1, v2] to remove values.

requestBody.description: List of changes.

200.description: Corresponding time series after applying the updates.

409.description: Time series with specified externalId already exists

x-code-samples.source:
res = client.time_series.retrieve(id=1)
res.description = "New description"
res = client.time_series.update(res)
from cognite.client.data_classes import TimeSeriesUpdate
my_update = TimeSeriesUpdate(id=1).description.set("New description").metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.time_series.update(my_update)

post.description: Deletes the time series with the specified IDs.

requestBody.description: Specify a list of the time series to delete.

post.description:
Insert datapoints into a time series. You can do this for multiple time series.
If you insert a datapoint with a timestamp that already exists, it will be overwritten with the new value.

requestBody.description: The datapoints to insert.

schema.description: Accepts protocol buffer serialised payload, based on following proto definitions: [Data Point Insertion](<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cognitedata/protobuf-files/master/v1/timeseries/data_point_insertion_request.proto>) and [Data Points](<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cognitedata/protobuf-files/master/v1/timeseries/data_points.proto>)

400.description: IDs or external IDs not found.

x-code-samples.source:
datapoints = []
datapoints.append({"id": 1, "datapoints": [(datetime(2018,1,1), 1000), (datetime(2018,1,2), 2000)]})
datapoints.append({"externalId": 1, "datapoints": [(150000000000, 1000), (160000000000, 2000)]})
client.datapoints.insert_multiple(datapoints)
datapoints = []
datapoints.append({"externalId": "1", "datapoints": [{"timestamp": datetime(2018,1,1), "value": 1000},
                    {"timestamp": datetime(2018,1,2), "value": 2000}]})
datapoints.append({"id": 1, "datapoints": [{"timestamp": 150000000000, "value": 1000},
                    {"timestamp": 160000000000, "value": 2000}]})
client.datapoints.insert_multiple(datapoints)

post.description: Retrieves a list of data points from multiple time series in a project. This operation supports aggregation, but not pagination. You can also use GET for this operation if you supply the post body as a query parameter named postBody.

requestBody.description: Specify parameters to query for multiple datapoints. If you omit fields in individual datapoint query items, the top-level field values are used. For example, you can specify a default limit for all items by setting the top-level limit field. If you request aggregates, only the aggregates are returned. If you don't request any aggregates, all data points are returned.

200.description: Lists of datapoints for the specified queries.

schema.description: Return protocol buffer serialised payload, based on the following proto definitions: [Data Points List](<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cognitedata/protobuf-files/master/v1/timeseries/data_point_list_response.proto>) and [Data Points](<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cognitedata/protobuf-files/master/v1/timeseries/data_points.proto>)

x-code-samples.source: const data = await client.datapoints.retrieve({ items: [{ id: 123 }] });

dps = client.datapoints.retrieve(id=1, start="2w-ago", end="now")
dps = client.datapoints.retrieve(external_id=["abc", "def"],
                        start=datetime(2018,1,1),
                        end=datetime(2019,1,1),
                        aggregates=["average"],
                        granularity="1d")
dps = client.datapoints.retrieve(id=[{"id": 1, "aggregates": ["average"]},
                            {"id": 1, "aggregates": ["min"]}],
                        external_id={"externalId": "1", "aggregates": ["max"]},
                        start="1d-ago", end="now", granularity="1h")

post.description: Retrieves the latest data point in a time series.

requestBody.description: The list of the queries to perform.

200.description: A list of responses. Each response contains a list with the most recent datapoint, or an empty list if no datapoints are found.

400.description: The time series does not exist.

x-code-samples.source:
res = client.datapoints.retrieve_latest(id=1)[0]
res = client.datapoints.retrieve_latest(id=1, before="2d-ago")[0]
res = client.datapoints.retrieve_latest(external_id=["abc", "def"])
latest_abc = res[0][0]
latest_def = res[1][0]

post.description: Delete datapoints from time series.

parameters.name: project
parameters.description: Project name.

requestBody.description: The list of delete requests to perform.

x-code-samples.source: await client.datapoints.delete([{id: 123, inclusiveBegin: new Date('1 jan 2019')}]);

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limit on the number of databases to be returned.

post.description: Create databases in a project. It is possible to post a maximum of 1000 databases per request.

requestBody.description: List of names of databases to be created.

x-code-samples.source: const databases = await client.raw.createDatabases([{ name: 'My company' }]);

post.description: It deletes a database, but fails if the database is not empty and recursive is set to false (default).

requestBody.description: List of names of the databases to be deleted.

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: The name of a database to retrieve tables from.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limit on the number of tables to be returned.

200.description: A list of tables in the database

post.description: Create tables in a database. It is possible to post a maximum of 1000 tables per request.

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database to create tables in.

parameters.name: ensureParent
parameters.description: Create database if it doesn't exist already

requestBody.description: List of tables to create.

x-code-samples.source: const tables = await client.raw.createTables('My company', [{ name: 'Customers' }]);

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database to delete tables in.

requestBody.description: List of tables to delete.

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database.

parameters.name: tableName
parameters.description: Name of the table.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limit the number of results.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.description: Ordered list of column keys, separated by commas. Leave empty for all, use single comma to retrieve only row keys.

parameters.name: minLastUpdatedTime
parameters.description: It is an exclusive filter, specifed as the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 00:00:00 Thursday, 1 January 1970, Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), minus leap seconds.

parameters.name: maxLastUpdatedTime
parameters.description: It is an inclusive filter, specifed as the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 00:00:00 Thursday, 1 January 1970, Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), minus leap seconds.

post.description:
Insert rows into a table. It is possible to post a maximum of 10000 rows per request.
It will replace the columns of an existing row if the rowKey already exists.

The rowKey is limited to 1024 characters which also includes Unicode characters.
The maximum size of columns are 5 MiB, however the maximum size of one column name and value is 2621440 characters each.
If you want to store huge amount of data per row or column we recommend using the Files API to upload blobs, then reference it from the Raw row.

The columns object is a key value object, where the key corresponds to the column name while the value is the column value.
It supports all the valid types of values in JSON, so number, string, array, and even nested JSON structure (see payload example to the right).

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database.

parameters.name: tableName
parameters.description: Name of the table.

parameters.name: ensureParent
parameters.description: Create database/table if it doesn't exist already

requestBody.description: List of rows to create.

x-code-samples.source: await client.raw.insertRows('My company', 'Customers', [{ key: 'customer1', columns: { 'First name': 'Steve', 'Last name': 'Jobs' } }]);

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database to retrieve the row from.

parameters.name: tableName
parameters.description: Name of the table to retrieve the row from.

parameters.name: rowKey
parameters.description: Row key of the row to retrieve.

200.description: Single row from the raw database table with the specified rowKey.

parameters.name: dbName
parameters.description: Name of the database containing the rows.

parameters.name: tableName
parameters.description: Name of the table containing the rows.

requestBody.description: Keys to the rows to delete.

get.description: Returns the authentication information about the asking entity.

x-code-samples.source:
const status = await client.login.status();
// if status === null means you are not logged in

get.description: Redirects to a login URL. This endpoint is typically used by front-end services acting on behalf of users to log them in.

parameters.name: project
parameters.description: The project to login to.

parameters.name: redirectUrl
parameters.description: The url to send the user to after the login is successful.

parameters.name: errorRedirectUrl
parameters.description: The url to send the user to if the login fails or is aborted. If this is not passed in, the value of the redirectUrl will be used.

get.description: Checks if a JWT ([JSON Web Token](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON_Web_Token)) is valid.

parameters.name: token
parameters.description: A JWT acquired from Cognite

200.description: Returns information on whether the token is valid.

get.description: Ask this with any valid credentials to obtain information about the current authenticated entity. The response is a decoded idToken.
Invalidates a session and returns the authentication status of the asking entity.
Get logout url of the given project.

parameters.name: redirectUrl
parameters.description: The url to send the user to after the logout is successful. If no url is passed, you will end up at the IDPs log out page.

data.title: URL Response
data.description: Object containing the log out URL

url.description: The url to send the user to in order to log out

get.description: Retrieves a list of groups the asking service account is a member of. Service accounts with groups:list capability can optionally ask for all groups in a project.

parameters.name: all
parameters.description: Whether to get all groups, only available with the groups:list acl.

x-code-samples.source: const groups = await client.groups.list({ all: true });

post.description: Creates one or more named groups, each with a set of capabilities.

requestBody.description: List of groups to create.

201.description: A list of the created groups.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import Group
my_capabilities = [{"groupsAcl": {"actions": ["LIST"],"scope": {"all": { }}}}]
my_group = Group(name="My Group", capabilities=my_capabilities)
res = client.iam.groups.create(my_group)

post.description: Deletes the groups with the given IDs.

get.summary: List service accounts in a group
get.description: Retrieve a list of service accounts that are members of the group with the given ID.

parameters.name: groupId
parameters.description: id of the group

post.summary: Add service accounts to a group
post.description: Grant the service accounts with the given IDs membership in a group. This operation is not idempotent; If any of the given users is already a member of the group, the operation will fail.

parameters.name: groupId
parameters.description: id of the group

requestBody.description: ids of service accounts to add

post.summary: Remove service accounts from a group
post.description: Revoke membership in a group from the given service accounts.

parameters.name: groupId
parameters.description: id of the group

requestBody.description: List of service account ids to remove

get.description: Retrieves information about a project given the project name.

put.description: Updates the full project. Be careful with this operation, as it will also override any previously set field. This means every call to this endpoint needs to also include the oauth credentials, otherwise they get unset. The urlName property can not be changed.

parameters.name: project
parameters.description: Project name.

requestBody.description: List of projects to update, with new values. Currently only supports one project.
List of service accounts to create.

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import ServiceAccount
my_account = ServiceAccount(name="my@service.com", groups=[1, 2, 3])
res = client.iam.service_accounts.create(my_account)

requestBody.description: List of service account ids to delete

get.description: Retrieves a list of all API keys connected to the current service account. Administrators can optionally list keys for all or individual service accounts that are not their own.

parameters.name: all
parameters.description: Only available with users:list ACL, returns all API keys for the project.

parameters.name: serviceAccountId
parameters.description: Get API keys for a specific service account, only available to admin users.

parameters.name: includeDeleted
parameters.description: Whether to include deleted API keys, or not.

x-code-samples.source: const apiKeys = await client.apiKeys.list({ all: true });

post.description: Creates one API key for each service account.

requestBody.description: List of the service accounts to create API keys for.

201.description: A list of the created API keys.

post.description: Deletes one or more API keys with the specified API key IDs. The API key IDs were returned when the keys were created, or can be obtained by listing all API keys.

requestBody.description: List of the IDs of the API keys to delete.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: Sort descending or ascending.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Cursor to use for paging through results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Return up to this many results. Maximum is 1000. Default is 25.

requestBody.description: List of categories to create

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import SecurityCategory
my_category = SecurityCategory(name="My Category")
res = client.iam.security_categories.create(my_category)

requestBody.description: List of security category IDs to delete.

get.description: List sequences. Use nextCursor to paginate through the results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limits the number of results to be returned. The maximum results returned by the server is 1000 even if you specify a higher limit.

200.description: Paged response with list of sequences.

x-code-samples.source: const sequences = await client.sequences.list({ filter: { name: 'sequence_name' } });

post.description: Create one or more sequences.

requestBody.description: Sequence to be stored

x-code-samples.source:
from cognite.client.data_classes import Sequence
client.lumn_def = [{"valueType":"STRING","externalId":"user","description":"some description"}, {"valueType":"DOUBLE","externalId":"amount"}]
seq = client.sequences.create(Sequence(external_id="my_sequence", columns=column_def))
seq2 = client.sequences.create(Sequence(external_id="my_copied_sequence", columns=seq.columns))

post.description: Retrieves a list of sequences matching the given criteria.

requestBody.description: Retrieves a list of sequences matching the given criteria.

x-code-samples.source: const sequences = await client.sequences.list({ filter: { name: 'sequence_name' } });

post.description: Retrieve one or more sequences by ID or external ID. The sequences are returned in the same order as in the request.

requestBody.description: Ids of the sequences

post.description: Retrieves a list of sequences matching the given criteria. This operation does not support pagination.

requestBody.description: Retrieves a list of sequences matching the given criteria. This operation does not support pagination.

post.description: Update one or more sequences. Fields that are not included in the request, are not changed.

requestBody.description: Patch definition

x-code-samples.source:
res = client.sequences.retrieve(id=1)
res.description = "New description"
res = client.sequences.update(res)
from cognite.client.data_classes import SequenceUpdate
my_update = SequenceUpdate(id=1).description.set("New description").metadata.add({"key": "value"})
res = client.sequences.update(my_update)

post.description: Deletes the sequences with the specified IDs.

requestBody.description: Ids of the sequences to delete

post.description: Inserts rows into a sequence. This overwrites data in rows and columns that exist.

requestBody.description: Data posted

x-code-samples.source:
seq = client.sequences.create(Sequence(columns=[{"valueType": "STRING", "externalId":"col_a"},{"valueType": "DOUBLE", "externalId":"col_b"}]))
data = [(1, ['pi',3.14]), (2, ['e',2.72]) ]
client.sequences.data.insert(column_external_ids=["col_a","col_b"], rows=data, id=1)
data = [{"rowNumber": 123, "values": ['str',3]}, {"rowNUmber": 456, "values": ["bar",42]} ]
client.sequences.data.insert(data, id=1, column_external_ids=["col_a","col_b"]) # implicit columns are retrieved from metadata
data = {123 : ['str',3], 456 : ['bar',42] }
client.sequences.data.insert(column_external_ids=['stringColumn','intColumn'], rows=data, id=1)
data = client.sequences.data.retrieve(id=2,start=0,end=10)
client.sequences.data.insert(rows=data, id=1,column_external_ids=None)

post.description: Processes data requests, and returns the result. NB - This operation uses a dynamic limit on the number of rows returned based on the number and type of columns, use the provided cursor to paginate and retrieve all data.

requestBody.description: Description of data requested

x-code-samples.source: const rows = await client.sequences.retrieveRows({ externalId: 'sequence1' }).autoPagingToArray({ limit: 100 });

res = client.sequences.data.retrieve(id=0, start=0, end=None)
tuples = [(r,v) for r,v in res.items()] # You can use this iterator in for loops and list comprehensions,
single_value = res[23] # ... get the values at a single row number,
client.l = res.get_column(external_id='columnExtId') # ... get the array of values for a specific column,
df = res.to_pandas() # ... or convert the result to a dataframe

post.description: Deletes the given rows of the sequence. All columns are affected.

requestBody.description: Indicate the sequences and the rows where data should be deleted

api-key.description: An admin can create API keys in the Cognite console.

token.description: Human users log in via an OpenId/OAuth flow. Use the /login/redirect flow to obtain a bearer access token. Use a header key of 'Authorization' with a value of 'Bearer $accesstoken'

ignoreUnknownIds.description: Ignore IDs and external IDs that are not found

missing.description: List of lookup objects that do not match any results.

duplicated.description: List of objects that are not unique.

ObjectPatch.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value. Limits: Maximum length of key is 32 bytes, value 512 bytes, up to 16 key-value pairs.

set.description: Set the key-value pairs. All existing key-value pairs will be removed.

add.description: Add the key-value pairs. Values for existing keys will be overwritten.

remove.description: Remove the key-value pairs with the specified keys.

ArrayPatchLong.description: Change that will be applied to the array.

EpochTimestamp.description: The number of milliseconds since 00:00:00 Thursday, 1 January 1970, Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), minus leap seconds.

partition.description:
Splits the data set into N partitions.
You need to follow the cursors within each partition in order to receive all the data.
Example: 1/10

SinglePatchRequiredString.title: set

limit.description: <- Limits the maximum number of results to be returned by single request. In case there are more results to the request 'nextCursor' attribute will be provided as part of response. Request may contain less results than request limit.

sort.description:
Sort by array of selected fields. Syntax: `["<fieldname>:asc|desc"]`. Default sort order is `asc` with short syntax: `["<fieldname>"]`. 
Filter accepts the following field names: startTime, endTime, createdTime, lastUpdatedTime. 
Partitions are done independently of sorting, there is no guarantee on sort order between elements from different partitions.

parentId.description: The parent of the node, null if it is the root node.

depth.description: The depth of the node in the tree, starting from 0 at the root node.

subtreeSize.description: The number of descendants of the node, plus one (counting itself).

UpdateRevision3DThumbnail.description: Request body for the updateModelRevisionThumbnail endpoint.

datapoints.description: The list of datapoints. The limit per request is 100000 datapoints.

TimestampOrStringStart.description:
Get datapoints starting from, and including, this time. The format is N[timeunit]-ago where
timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' gets datapoints that are up to 2 days
old. You can also specify time in milliseconds since epoch. Note that for aggregates, the start time is rounded down to a whole granularity unit (in UTC timezone). Daily granularities (d)
are rounded to 0:00 AM; hourly granularities (h) to the start of the hour, etc.

TimestampOrStringEnd.description: Get datapoints up to, but excluding, this point in time. Same format as for start. Note that when using aggregates, the end will be rounded up such that the last aggregate represents a full aggregation interval containing the original end, where the interval is the granularity unit times the granularity multiplier. For granularity 2d, the aggregation interval is 2 days, if end was originally 3 days after the start, it will be rounded to 4 days after the start.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints. Maximum is 100000 non-aggregated data points and 10000 aggregated data points.

aggregates.description: Specify the aggregates to return, or an empty array if this sub-query should return datapoints without aggregation. This value overrides a top-level default aggregates list.

granularity.description: The time granularity size and unit to aggregate over.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period, and the first one after. This option is useful for interpolating data. It is not available for aggregates.

DatapointsQuery.description: Parameters describing a query for datapoints.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints.

aggregates.description: Specify the aggregates to return. Use default if null. If the default is a set of aggregates, specify an empty string to get raw data.

items.description: Specify the aggregates to return. Use default if null. If the default is a set of aggregates, specify an empty string to get raw data.

granularity.description: The granularity size and granularity of the aggregates.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after. This option can be useful for interpolating data. It is not available for aggregates.

items.description: List of latest queries

before.description:
Get datapoints before this time. The format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s.
Example: '2d-ago' gets data that is up to 2 days old. You can also specify time in milliseconds since epoch.

items.description: List of delete filters

DatapointsDeleteRequest.description: Select time series and datapoints to delete.

inclusiveBegin.description: The timestamp of first datapoint to delete.

exclusiveEnd.description: The timestamp of the first datapoint after inclusiveBegin to not delete. If not set, only deletes the datapoint at inclusiveBegin.

items.description: List of ID objects

externalId.description: Externally provided ID for the time series (optional, but recommended.)

name.description: Human readable name of the time series. This field is seperate from name field available through API versions 0.3-0.6.

legacyName.description: Set a value for legacyName to allow applications using API v0.3, v04, v05, and v0.6 to access this time series. The legacy name is the human-readable name for the time series and is mapped to the name field used in API versions 0.3-0.6. The legacyName field value must be unique, and setting this value to an already existing value will return an error. We recommend that you set this field to the same value as externalId.

isString.description: Whether the time series is string valued or not.

unit.description: The physical unit of the time series.

assetId.description: The asset that this time series belongs to.

isStep.description: Whether the time series is a step series or not.

description.description: A description of the time series.

securityCategories.description: The required security categories to access this time series.

items.description: The required security categories to access this time series.

timestamp.description: The data timestamp in milliseconds since the epoch (Jan 1, 1970).

average.description: The integral average value in the aggregate period.

max.description: The maximum value in the aggregate period.

min.description: The minimum value in the aggregate period.

count.description: The number of datapoints in the aggregate period.

sum.description: The sum of the datapoints in the aggregate period.

interpolation.description: The interpolated value of the series in the beginning of the aggregate.

stepInterpolation.description: The last value before or at the beginning of the aggregate.

continuousVariance.description: The variance of the interpolated underlying function.

discreteVariance.description: The variance of the datapoint values.

totalVariation.description: The total variation of the interpolated underlying function.

nextCursor.description: Cursor to get the next page of results (if available).

SecurityCategoryWithCursorResponse.description: A list of objects along with possible cursors to get the next page of results

nextCursor.description: The cursor to get the next page of results (if available). Learn more [here](/dev/concepts/pagination/).

ColumnExternalId.description: User provided column identifier. Should be unique for a given sequence.

SequenceDataRequest.description: Parameters describing a query for datapoints.

SequenceDeleteDataRequest.description: Parameters describing datapoints to be deleted

assetId.description: Optional asset this sequence is associated with

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value. Maximum length of key is 32 bytes, value 512 bytes, up to 16 key-value pairs.

GetSequenceDTO.description: Information about the sequence stored in the database

id.description: Unique cognite-provided identifier for the sequence

assetId.description: Optional asset this sequence is associated with

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value. Maximum length of key is 32 bytes, value 512 bytes, up to 16 key-value pairs.

createdTime.description: Time when this asset was created in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

lastUpdatedTime.description: The last time this asset was updated in CDP, in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

CreatedSequenceDTO.description: Information about the sequence stored in the database

id.description: Unique cognite-provided identifier for the sequence

assetId.description: Optional asset this sequence is associated with

externalId.description: Projectwide unique identifier for the sequence

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value

createdTime.description: Time when this asset was created in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

lastUpdatedTime.description: The last time this asset was updated in CDP, in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

name.description: Human readable name of the sequence

externalId.description: User provided column identifier (Unique for a given sequence)

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value

GetSequenceColumnDTO.description: Information about a column stored in the database

name.description: Human readable name of the column

externalId.description: User provided column identifier (Unique for a given sequence)

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value

createdTime.description: Time when this asset was created in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

lastUpdatedTime.description: The last time this asset was updated in CDP, in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

CreatedSequenceColumnDTO.description: Information about a column stored in the database

name.description: Human readable name of the column

externalId.description: User provided column identifier (Unique for a given sequence)

metadata.description: Custom, application specific metadata. String key -> String value

createdTime.description: Time when this asset was created in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

lastUpdatedTime.description: The last time this asset was updated in CDP, in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

end.description: Get rows up to, but excluding, this row number. Default - No limit

limit.description: Maximum number of rows returned in one request. Api might return less even if there is more data, but it will then provide a cursor for continuation. If there is more data beyond this limit, a cursor will be returned to simplify further fetching of data.

cursor.description: Cursor for pagination returned from a previous request. Apart from this cursor, the rest of the request object have be the same as for the original request.

columns.description: Columns to be included. Specified as list of column externalIds. In case this filter is not set, all available columns will be returned.

SequenceDataDeleteRequestDTO.description: rows to delete from a sequence

columns.description: Column information in order given by data

nextCursor.description: Cursor to get the next page of results (if available).

columns.description: Column external ids in the same order as the values for each row

BasicGetSequenceColumnInfo.description: Column information returned on data requests

externalId.description: User provided column identifier (Unique for a given sequence)

name.description: Human readable name of the column

rowNumber.description: The row number for this row

values.description: List of values in order defined in the columns field (Number of items must match. Null is accepted for missing values)

SequenceItemDTO.description: Json element of type corresponding to the column type. May include NULL!

update.description: A description of changes that should be done to the sequence

name.description: Return only sequences with this *exact* name.

metadata.description: Filter the sequences by metadata fields and values (case-sensitive). Format is {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2"}.

assetIds.description: Return only sequences linked to one of the specified assets.

rootAssetIds.description: Return only sequences linked to assets with one of these assets as the root asset.

createdTime.description: Filter out sequences with createdTime outside this range.

lastUpdatedTime.description: Filter out sequences with lastUpdatedTime outside this range.

name.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on name.

description.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on description.

query.description: Search on name and description using wildcard search on each of the words (separated by spaces). Retrieves results where at least one word must match. Example: '*some* *other*'

limit.description: Return up to this many results.
Return up to this many results per page.

cursor.description: Cursor for paging trough results. Still keep the filter in subsequent requests.

SequenceValueTypeEnum.description: What type the datapoints in a column will have. DOUBLE is restricted to the range [-1E100, 1E100]

partition.name: partition
partition.description:
Splits the data set into N partitions.
You need to follow the cursors within each partition in order to receive all the data.
Example: 1/10

Offset.name: offset
Offset.description: Offset from the first result. Sum of limit and offset must not exceed 1000.

Limit.name: limit
Limit.description: Limits the number of results to be returned. The maximum results returned by the server is 1000 even if you specify a higher limit.

items.description: Fields that are missing.

ErrorResponse.description: The response for a failed request.

AssetDataWithCursorResponse.description: Paged response with list of assets.

EventDataResponse.description: Paged response with list of events

EventDataWithCursorResponse.description: Paged response with list of events

FileMetadataResponse.description: The response for a successful GET files/id operation

UploadFileMetadataResponse.description: The response for a successful files operation

uploadUrl.description: The URL where the file contents should be uploaded.

FileMetadataWithCursorResponse.description: The response for a successful files/list operation

FileResponse.description: The response for a successful files/byids, files/search or files/update operation

DataWithLinks.description: The response for a successful files/downloadlink operation.

LoginStatusResponse.description: Information about the current logged in entity

items.description: List of service accounts

tags.name: Assets
tags.description: The assets resource type stores digital representations of objects or  groups of objects from the physical world. Assets are organized in hierarchies.  For example, a water pump asset can be part of a subsystem asset on an  oil platform asset.

tags.name: Events
tags.description:
Event objects store complex information about multiple assets over a time period. For example, an event can describe two hours of maintenance on a water pump and some associated pipes, or a future time window where the pump is scheduled for inspection. This is in contrast with data points in time series that store single pieces of information about one asset at specific points in time (e.g., temperature measurements).

An event’s time period is defined by a start time and end time, both millisecond timestamps since the UNIX epoch. The timestamps can be in the future. In addition, events can have a text description as well as arbitrary metadata and properties.

Asset references obtained from an event - through asset ids - may be invalid, simply by the non-transactional nature of HTTP. They are maintained in an eventual consistent manner.

tags.name: Files
tags.description:
A file stores a sequence of bytes connected to one or more assets. For
example, a file can contain a piping and instrumentation diagram (P&IDs)
showing how multiple assets are connected.

Each file is identified by the 'id' field, which is generated internally 
for each new file. Each file's 'id' field is unique within a project.

The 'externalId' field is optional, but can also be used to identify a file. 
The 'externalId' (if used) must be unique within a project.

Files are created in two steps; First the metadata is stored in a file
object, and then the file contents are uploaded. This means that files can
exist in a non-uploaded state. The upload state is reflected in the 'uploaded' 
field in responses.


Asset references obtained from a file - through asset ids - may be
invalid, simply by the non-transactional nature of HTTP.
They are maintained in an eventual consistent manner.

tags.name: 3D
tags.description:
We organize 3D data into models and revisions. A model is just a placeholder for a set of revisions. Revisions contains the actual 3D data. For example you can have a model named Compressor and you can upload a revision under that model. When you create a revision you need to attach a 3D file. For every new version of the 3D model you upload a new revision under the placeholder model. You can then easily track the history of a model by browsing the different revisions.

When you upload a new revision Cognite need to process the 3D data to optimize it for rendering. This can take some time and we therefore give you a status string back in the revision object. You can then follow the process while you wait.

A 3D model is typically built up by a hierarchical structure. This looks very similar to how we organize our internal asset hierarchy. We support endpoints to extract the 3D node hierarchy and endpoints to make mappings from the 3D nodes to nodes in Cognite's asset hierarchy. We assign a random ID, nodeId, to each node in the 3D hierarchy. This is the ID representing the object in the viewer. When a user click on a object in the viewer it returns the ID for the object that was clicked. You can then use that ID to look up which node in the hierarchy the user clicked on.

We also deliver a [web based 3D viewer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@cognite/3d-viewer) to embed the 3D model in your own web page.

tags.name: Time series
tags.description:
A time series consists of a sequence of data points connected to a single asset. 

For example: A water pump asset can have a temperature time series that records a data point in units of °C every second. 

A single asset can have several time series. The water pump could have additional time series measuring pressure within the pump, rpm, flow volume, power consumption, and more.

Time series store data points as either number or strings. This is controlled by the is_string flag on the time series object. Numerical data points can be aggregated before they are returned from a query (e.g., to find the average temperature for a day). String data points, on the other hand, cannot be aggregated by CDF, but can store arbitrary information like states (e.g. “open”/”closed”) or more complex information (JSON).

Cognite stores discrete data points, but the underlying process measured by the data points can vary continuously. When interpolating between data points, we can either assume that each value stays the same until the next measurement, or that it linearly changes between the two measurements. This is controlled by the is_step flag on the time series object. For example, if we estimate the average over a time containing two data points, the average will either be close to the first (is step) or close to the mean of the two (not is step).

A data point stores a single piece of information, a number or a string, associated with a specific time. Data points are identified by their timestamps, measured in milliseconds since the unix epoch -- 00:00, January 1st, 1970. Milliseconds is the finest time resolution supported by CDF i.e. fractional milliseconds are not supported. Leap seconds are not counted.

Numerical data points can be aggregated before they are retrieved from CDF. This allows for faster queries by reducing the amount of data transferred. You can aggregate data points by specifying one or more aggregates (e.g. average, minimum, maximum) as well as the time granularity over which the aggregates should be applied (e.g. “1h” for one hour).

Aggregates are aligned to the start time modulo the granularity unit. For example, if you ask for daily average temperatures since Monday afternoon last week, the first aggregated data point will contain averages for Monday, the second for Tuesday, etc. Determining aggregate alignment without considering data point timestamps allows CDF to pre-calculate aggregates (e.g. to quickly return daily average temperatures for a year). As a consequence, aggregating over 60 minutes can return a different result that aggregating over 1 hour because the two queries will be aligned differently. 

Asset references obtained from a time series - through its asset id - may be invalid, simply by the non-transactional nature of HTTP. They are maintained in an eventual consistent manner.

tags.name: Raw
tags.description: Manage data in the raw NoSQL database. Each project will have a variable number of raw databases, each of which will have a variable number of tables, each of which will have a variable number of key-value objects. Only queries on key are supported through this API.

tags.name: Login
tags.description: A user that is only manifested in an external IDP needs to authenticate towards that IDP and not Cognite directly. Our login endpoints gives some mechanism for both redirecting to the IDP for a given project as well as getting information about the currently authenticated user. For a service account manifested in CDF, there's no reason to logging in. To validate that the key is valid, you can ask for authentication information about the logged in entity.

tags.name: Logout
tags.description: Logging out a user means invalidating the token granted by CDF on the behalf of the external IDP. Optionally, you can also get a logout url to log out of the IDP itself (Azure AD, Google etc). Logging out is only effective for tokens (not api keys).

tags.name: Projects
tags.description: Projects are used to separate customers from one another, and all objects in CDF are linked to a project. The project object contains configuration for how to authenticate users.

tags.name: Service accounts
tags.description: Manage service accounts for a specific project.

tags.name: Sequences
tags.description:
A sequence stores a table with up to 200 columns indexed by row number. Each of  the columns has a pre-defined type which is a string, integer, or floating point number.

For example, a sequence can represent a curve, either with the dependent variable x as the row number  and a single value column y, or can simply store (x,y) pair in the rows directly. Other potential applications include data logs in which the index is not time-based.
To learn more about sequences, see the [concept guide](/dev/concepts/resource_types/sequences.html).
